sn22.116:1.2: Seated to one side, that monk said to the Buddha:
sn22.116:1.4: How is a Dhamma speaker defined?
sn22.116:1.5: How is a monk who practices in line with the teaching defined? And how is a monk who has attained extinguishment in this very life defined?”
sn22.116:1.6: “Monk, if a monk teaches Dhamma for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form, they’re qualified to be called a ‘monk who speaks on Dhamma’.
sn22.116:1.7: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form, they’re qualified to be called a ‘monk who practices in line with the teaching’.
sn22.116:1.8: If they’re freed by not grasping by disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding form, they’re qualified to be called a ‘monk who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.
sn22.116:1.9: If a monk teaches Dhamma for disillusionment with feeling …
sn22.116:1.12: consciousness, for its fading away and cessation, they’re qualified to be called a ‘monk who speaks on Dhamma’.
sn22.116:1.13: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding consciousness, they’re qualified to be called a ‘monk who practices in line with the teaching’.
sn22.116:1.14: If they’re freed by not grasping by disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding consciousness, they’re qualified to be called a ‘monk who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.”
